resources.string: Which URL shall the certificate be fetched from?
The certificate chain doesn\'t contain a valid certificate for the host name in the URL. Use the correct host name or change the corresponding certificate\'s subject.
The certificate chain is already trusted. You don\'t need to import a certificate.
Is a CA (may issue certificates), max. path length: %s
Is not a CA (must not issue certificates)
Basic Constraints extension not present, thus no CA flag
The certificate has expired or is not yet valid.

X.509 v3+ certificates may contain the Basic Constraints extension. It contains a CA flag and optionally, a path length constraint. Android will only accept CA certificates when they have a CA flag set to TRUE. Otherwise, it\'s assumed that this CA mustn\'t issue certificates, not even for itself (self-signed).

There\'s no CA flag=TRUE in this certificate, so Android can\'t import it. Trying so wouldn\'t result in an error message, but the certificate wouldn\'t appear in the list and wouldn\'t be trusted.

Solution: Set the CA flag to TRUE when using a self-signed certificate.
The certificate has been exported. Remember the file name because you may have to select it in the next step:

The certificate has been stored on your "external storage". Now you can import it to your Android device using Android Settings (Security):

1. Click \"Open Settings\" to open Android Settings.

2. Scroll down to \"Credential Storage\".

3. Use \"Install from SD card\" (the exact term may differ) and follow the instructions.

Note 1: You may have to set up a PIN or password for the lock screen (Android bug #31101).

Note 2: On Android 4.4+, there will be a strange \"Network may be monitored\" warning (Android bug #62644).

4. After installing the certificate, you can verify whether it worked by using \"Trusted credentials (Display trusted CA certificates)\" in Settings (Security). Your CA should appear in the \"User\" tab.
The certificate has not been imported successfully yet (and thus won\'t be trusted yet).
The certificate has been imported successfully. You may now use any Android app like DAVdroid or the stock email app to connect to this host.
The sub-domain part to use for this device
Sets on or off the publishing
IP or host providing UDDNS service
Port the UDDNS service is listening on
Downloads the server cert on your device.
Your username on the UDDNS server.
